section.heading: Medical Professional Liability Closed Claim Form.

para.text: A hospital shall complete and submit to the Department the approved Medical Professional Liability Closed Claim form, for each medical liability claim filed regarding the care or services received by a patient under the care of that hospital.

Regardless of the result of a closed claim, the hospital shall submit the Medical Professional Liability Closed Claim form to the Department within 90 days after the end of the quarter during which the final judgment, settlement, or final disposition of the claim was made.
This regulation does not:
Limit the right of an individual to make a gift under the Anatomical Gift Act, Estates and Trusts Article, Title 4, Subtitle 5, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Interfere with the duties of the office of the Chief Medical Examiner.
A hospital shall develop and follow a protocol in accordance with this regulation for the procurement of organs and tissues.
Requests for Donation on Death of Patient.

In accordance with this regulation, whenever a patient of a hospital meets the following criteria, the administrator of the hospital shall designate a person to request that the representative of the patient consent to the donation of the organs and tissues of the patient:
The patient may be pronounced dead in accordance with Health-General Article, §5-202, Annotated Code of Maryland;
The patient has not given actual notice of an objection to the donation of his or her organs and tissues; and
The patient has not made a gift of all or part of his or her body under the Anatomical Gift Act, Estates and Trusts Article, Title 4, Subtitle 5, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A hospital may not make a request for consent to a donation if the use of all of the organs or tissues of the patient is medically contraindicated.
In making a request required in §C(1), of this regulation, the hospital designee shall:
Make a reasonable effort to locate and contact the appropriate person set forth in §D, of this regulation, as the representative of the deceased patient; and
Request that the representative consent to a donation of any organ or tissue of the patient which is suitable for donation.
Determination of Patient Representative for Consent to Donation.
The representative of a deceased patient shall be:
The spouse of the patient, but, if the spouse is not competent; then
Any adult son or daughter of the patient, but, if no adult child of the patient is competent; then
Either parent of the patient, but, if neither is competent; then
Any adult brother or sister of the patient, but, if no adult sibling of the patient is competent; then
Any guardian of the person of the patient, but, if the patient has no guardian of his or her person; then
Any other person authorized or obligated by law to dispose of the body of the patient.

If the death of a patient occurs suddenly and the patient was in apparent good health or unattended by a physician, the hospital shall notify and cooperate with the office of the Chief Medical Examiner before the removal of any organ or tissue.
Discretion and Sensitivity in Making Requests. In making a request for donation, the hospital designee shall show reasonable discretion and sensitivity to the:
Circumstances of the family of the patient;
Religious beliefs of the patient; and
Suitability of the organs or tissues for donation.
Documentation. The designee shall document in the medical record of the patient:
Any request made for donation of organs or tissues;
Any consent to donate organs or tissues;
Whether a donation is made and accepted;
Any objection to the donation made by:
The patient, or
An appropriate representative of a patient as set forth in §D of this regulation; and
The reason for electing not to make a request for organ or tissue donation.
Discharge Options. A hospital may discharge a patient:
Entirely;
To another level of care, treatment, or services;
To different health care professionals; or
To settings for continued services.
A hospital's process for transfer or discharge shall be based on a patient's assessed needs at the time of discharge.
To facilitate discharge or transfer, the hospital shall:
Assess the patient's needs beginning at an early stage of the patient's hospitalization and as the patient's needs change throughout the hospitalization;
Develop plans for the patient's discharge or transfer with input, if appropriate, from the patient, the family, or other interested party;

Identify appropriately qualified staff, such as registered nurses or licensed social workers, who have the knowledge and experience necessary to determine what services or type of providers can best meet the patient's discharge needs;
Arrange or help to arrange for services needed to meet the patient's needs after discharge; and

Provide the patient, or the provider who is responsible for providing continuing care to the patient, with written discharge instructions and other necessary medical information in a form the patient or provider can understand.

A licensed acute general hospital or special hospital shall comply with the Emergency Management standards outlined in the Hospital Accreditation Standards (2009 Edition), pages 47—68 with the exception of standard EM.02.02.13, pages 61—65.
A licensee shall prepare an executive summary of the hospital's evacuation procedures to provide to a patient, family member, or legal representative upon request. The summary shall:
Describe the hospital's Emergency Operation Plan (EOP), which is discussed throughout the Emergency Management standards cited in §A(1) of this regulation; and
Describe the role and responsibilities of a patient, family member, or legal representative in the event of an emergency situation.

A licensee shall have a tracking system to assist the hospital, family members, government representatives, and other authorized stakeholders, to locate and identify patients in the event of displacement due to an emergency or disaster.

section.heading: Notice to Patients of Outpatient on Observation Status.

para.text: A hospital shall provide both an oral and written notice to a patient of:
The patient’s outpatient on observation status;
The billing implications of the outpatient on observation status; and
The impact of the outpatient on observation status on the patient’s eligibility for Medicare rehabilitation services if:
The patient received on-site services from the hospital for more than 23 consecutive hours;
The on-site services received by the patient include a hospital bed and meals that have been provided in an area of the hospital other than the Emergency Department; and
The patient is classified as an outpatient at the hospital for observation rather than as an admitted inpatient.
The written notice shall include:
That the patient is considered to be on observation as an outpatient and is not admitted as an inpatient;
The reason or rationale that the patient has not been admitted for inpatient services;

That the patient, if needed upon discharge, may not qualify for Medicare Part A reimbursement for rehabilitation services, including such services provided under Medicare Part A in a skilled nursing facility;
That there may be billing implications based on their outpatient status that may increase the patient’s out-of-pocket costs for their stay;
The name and title of the staff who provided the oral notice stating the date and time of the oral notice; and
The signature of the patient to verify an understanding and receipt of the written notice.

Once the patient has received onsite services for more than 23 hours, the hospital shall provide written and oral notice to the patient that the physician has ordered services be provided as outpatient on observation status.
The oral and written notice shall be provided in a manner that is understood by the patient.

If the patient lacks capacity to understand the medical or financial implications of his or her outpatient on observation status, the oral and written notice shall be provided to a person authorized to make medical or financial decisions for the patient, including:
A guardian of the person under Estates and Trusts Article, §13-705, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A guardian of the property under Estates and Trusts Article, §13-201, Annotated Code of Maryland;
An agent appointed under an advance directive that meets the requirements of Health-General Article, §5-602, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A surrogate decision maker with authority under Health-General Article, §5-605, Annotated Code of Maryland;
An agent appointed under a power of attorney that meets the requirements of Estates and Trusts Article, Title 17, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A representative payee or other similar fiduciary; or

Any other person, if that person was designated by the patient who was competent at the time of designation, and the patient or representative has provided the hospital with documentation of the designation.

For Medicare patients only, a hospital has the option to provide only the notice required by Medicare under 42 CFR §489.20(y). Hospitals that elect to use that option shall be considered compliant with this regulation if the notice is provided to patients that receive on-site services for more than 23 hours.
The facility shall be in compliance with:
Guidelines for the Design and Construction of Hospitals and Outpatient Facilities (2014); and
All applicable State and local governing laws, regulations, standards, ordinances, and codes for fire safety, building, and zoning requirements.
Any waiver or other modification of these requirements shall be addressed by the appropriate State or local authority having jurisdiction in accordance with established procedures.

Acute general hospitals and special hospitals-chronic care with 50 or more beds shall establish an active hospitalwide palliative care program that provides consultation services to patients suffering from pain and symptoms due to serious illnesses or conditions.
The hospital shall:
Promote the palliative care program;
Provide information and referrals to patients and families when appropriate regarding the availability of palliative care services; and
Inform patients of the patient’s right to request a palliative care consultation.
Staffing.
The hospital shall designate a qualified interdisciplinary care team with training in palliative care to staff the palliative care program.
The hospital shall ensure that:
A qualified health care professional coordinates the activities of the palliative care program with the palliative care patient’s interdisciplinary care team;
Staff is appropriately trained, credentialed, or certified in the staff’s area of expertise;
Staff receives continuing training and education; and
Written policies and procedures for the hospital palliative care program are established, implemented, maintained, and updated periodically.
Palliative Care Education and Training. The hospital shall provide and document training to medical and other clinical staff as determined by the hospital regarding:
Services provided by the palliative care program;
Domains of palliative care; and
Legal requirements for:
Health care decisions; and
MOLST as referenced in COMAR 10.01.21.
Interdisciplinary Plan of Care.
The hospital shall incorporate the recommendations of the palliative care program into the palliative care patient’s interdisciplinary care plan.
The hospital shall review the interdisciplinary plan of care and revise it as necessary to meet the needs of the palliative care patient.
The palliative care program shall conduct care conferences as appropriate to review the plan of care with:
The palliative care patient;
The palliative care patient’s family;
The health care professionals; and
Other interdisciplinary team members.
Contents. The hospital shall ensure that the palliative care patient’s plan of care includes at a minimum:
Initial assessments conducted by the interdisciplinary palliative care team;
Psychological needs assessment;
Treatment goals;
Choice of treatment options;
Preferred care setting;
Availability of hospice services;
Preferred site of death and after-death arrangements, as appropriate;
Grief and bereavement plan, as appropriate;
Assessment of cultural needs;
Assessment of legal needs; and
Assessment of discharge needs.
Collaboration. The hospital shall document and provide palliative care services in collaboration with:
The attending physician; and
Any other health care provider managing the patient’s care.
Continuity of Care. The hospital shall coordinate services to ensure continuity of care for the palliative care patient. The hospital shall:
Transfer the pertinent parts of the medical record, medical orders, and plan of care with the palliative care patient upon transfer to post-acute care;
Ensure that MOLST forms are completed in accordance with COMAR 10.01.21;
Convert a palliative care patient’s treatment goals into medical orders, as appropriate; and
Have reporting mechanisms to keep all staff informed and updated about care changes and treatment goals.
Palliative Care Services.
The hospital or palliative care program shall counsel the palliative care patient or the patient’s authorized decision maker regarding:
Health options;
Pain management options;
Prognosis;
Risks and benefits of treatment;
Availability of grief and bereavement services, as appropriate;
Psychological services;
Availability of spiritual care counseling through the hospital or outpatient providers; and
Hospice services, as appropriate.
Referrals.
As appropriate and upon request by the patient or authorized decision maker, the hospital may make timely referrals.
The hospital shall document any referrals made to:
Inpatient or outpatient bereavement providers;
Psychological services for the palliative care patient and the patient’s family;
Inpatient or outpatient spiritual care services; and
Hospice.
Pain and Symptom Management. The hospital shall:
Conduct and document pain and symptom assessments using available standardized scales to appropriately manage a palliative care patient’s symptoms;
Provide adequate and appropriate dosage of analgesics and sedatives to meet the needs of the palliative care patient; and
Educate the patient and the patient’s family about the use of opioids during end-of-life care.

Other Services. The hospital shall provide culturally and linguistically appropriate education and support about how to safely care for the patient at home or in an alternate residential setting as appropriate.

Imminent Death. The palliative care program shall document and counsel the patient, the authorized decision maker, the patient’s family, and the interdisciplinary care team about the active dying phase and imminent death as appropriate.
MOLST. The hospital shall comply with the procedures and requirements of the Medical Orders for Life-Sustaining Treatment Form, which is incorporated by reference at COMAR 10.07.21.
Interpreter Services. The hospital shall ensure interpreter services are available and accessible to the palliative care program.
Advance Directives.
The hospital shall recognize the authority of:
An advance directive established in compliance with Health-General Article, §5-602, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
An authorized decision maker.
The hospital shall ensure that any provided advance directive and authorized decision maker designation are in the patient’s medical record, including the electronic medical record.
The hospital shall promote advance care planning and the completion of advance directives through community outreach activities.
Ethics Committee. The hospital shall allow staff, patients, and the patient’s family in the palliative care program access to an ethics committee to address ethical conflicts at the end of life.
Quality Improvement. The palliative care program shall take part in the hospital’s quality improvement and performance improvement activities to the extent required by State and federal statute.

Departmental Oversight. The Department shall have access to all data maintained through the hospital’s palliative care program to determine the hospital’s compliance with State and federal regulations.
The Secretary shall deny a license to a person who has been convicted of a felony that relates to Medicaid or to a nursing home.
The Secretary shall revoke the license of any licensee convicted of a felony that relates to Medicaid or to a nursing home.
The Secretary may deny or revoke a license if the hospital does not meet the requirements of:
Health-General Article, Title 19, Subtitle 3, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Any regulation adopted under Health-General Article, Title 19, Subtitle 3, Annotated Code of Maryland, including this chapter.

A hospital subject to a fine or a penalty, or to delicensure, denial, or revocation of license under these regulations, may request a hearing as set forth under State Government Article, §10-201 et seq., Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 10.01.03.
The Department may impose a civil money penalty not to exceed $10,000 for each failure of a hospital to comply with the requirements of Regulation .27 of this chapter.
In determining whether to impose a civil money penalty, the Department may consider the following factors:
The number of failures to comply;
The nature and seriousness of the failure to comply;
The degree of risk to the health, life, or safety of the patient being discharged that is caused by the failure to comply;
A hospital's prior history to comply with discharge requirements; and
Such other factors as justice may require.

section.heading: Civil Money Penalties — Payment of Penalty.

para.text: If a hospital owes a civil money penalty to the Department, the hospital shall adhere to the procedures of this regulation.
A civil money penalty payment is due to the Department 15 calendar days after:
The time period for requesting a hearing has expired if a request for hearing is not received; or

Receipt of a written request from the hospital to waive its right to a hearing and reduce the amount of the civil penalty by 40 percent, if the written request is received by the Department within 30 calendar days of the Department's order imposing the civil money penalty.

A hospital aggrieved by the imposition of a civil money penalty may appeal the action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Secretary has the burden of proof with respect to the imposition of civil money penalties.
Each hospital shall adopt and implement the following set of uniform codes for the identified emergency situations as part of its emergency or disaster plans:
Fire — Code Red;
Infant or Child Abduction — Code Pink;
Cardiac Respiratory Arrest — Code Blue — Adult;
Cardiac Respiratory Arrest — Code Blue — Child;
Cardiac Respiratory Arrest — Code Blue — Infant;
Combative Person — Code Green;
Bomb Threat — Code Gold;
Hazardous Material Spill or Release — Code Orange;
Elopement — Code Gray;
Security Only Response — Code Purple;
Emergency or Disaster — Code Yellow; and
Armed Assailant — Code Silver.
A hospital may adapt the uniform codes referenced in §A of this regulation to meet the specific needs of the hospital by adding a suffix or additional words after that code.
For emergency situations not addressed by the codes in §A of this regulation, a hospital may establish its own identifying code.
A hospital shall adopt only those uniform color codes that are consistent with the services or needs of the hospital.
As part of its emergency or disaster plan, the hospital shall establish its own protocol for each of the uniform codes.
A hospital shall provide orientation and training to all staff regarding the uniform emergency codes and the hospital's emergency or disaster plan.
A hospital seeking exceptions to the requirements of this regulation shall submit its plan for emergency codes to the Department for review and approval:
Within 90 days after the effective date of this regulation; or
Before implementation of changes in its emergency code that would not comply with §§A—F of this regulation.
The hospital shall have an active hospital-wide program for the prevention, control, and investigation of communicable diseases and infections.
Staffing.
The hospital shall designate qualified staff with training in infection prevention and control to be responsible for the implementation of the infection prevention and control program.
Additional clinical and support staff shall be provided for the infection prevention and control program based on the size and complexity of the hospital's services.
Infection Prevention and Control Program.
The infection prevention and control program shall be based on nationally recognized, evidence-based standards.
The infection prevention and control program shall be developed using an interdisciplinary approach with input from:
Administrative staff;
Medical staff;
Pharmacy staff;
Laboratory personnel;
Nursing staff;
Physical plant personnel;
Employee health personnel;
Patient safety officer; and
Staff from other departments whose knowledge and experience would contribute to improved infection prevention and control.
Written policies and procedures for the infection prevention and control program shall be established, implemented, maintained, and updated periodically.
Surveillance.
The hospital shall:
Have a process for the identification and surveillance of healthcare- associated infections;
Analyze and utilize surveillance data to monitor and improve infection control and healthcare outcomes; and
Maintain a log of the identified infections.
The infection prevention and control program shall include:
Processes for the monitoring and control of patients who have a communicable disease or infection to prevent its spread to other patients and staff;
A process to identify and investigate the occurrence of outbreaks of communicable diseases or clusters of infections; and
Reporting of infections, communicable diseases, and outbreaks to the local or State health department, as required by COMAR 10.06.01.
When an outbreak occurs, the infection control staff shall have adequate resources and authority to ensure comprehensive and timely investigation and to implement control measures.
Education.

The hospital shall provide education to all staff and, if appropriate, to the patient and visitors regarding the prevention and control of communicable diseases and infections. Educational activities shall address problems identified by the infection prevention and control program.
Nonclinical staff shall be included in infection prevention and control training consistent with their assigned responsibilities.
Attendance or participation in an educational program shall be recorded. Educational programs shall be evaluated not less than annually for effectiveness.
Education related to infection prevention and control shall be included in the hospital's orientation program for all new employees, including appropriate contractual personnel.

Physicians who are employed or who have privileges and who do not receive training through the hospital's new employee training program shall receive alternative orientation education on infection prevention and control practices and the hospital's infection prevention and control program.
Outside agency staff shall receive sufficient training in the hospital's infection prevention and control policies and procedures to provide safe care to the patients.
Prevention.
The hospital shall establish processes and programs to prevent the spread of communicable diseases and infections.
A hospital's processes and programs to prevent the spread of communicable diseases and infections shall include at least the items listed in §F(3) of this regulation.
Required Processes and Programs.
Hand Hygiene.

The infection prevention and control program shall include activities to educate staff on the need for hand hygiene prior to and after any patient contact and as directed by accepted professional practice.
Hand hygiene compliance by staff shall be monitored through the infection prevention and control program.
The infection prevention and control program shall maintain documentation of audits for compliance with this requirement.
Facilities and supplies to facilitate hand hygiene shall be provided and be accessible in all locations of the hospital where patient care is provided.
Sanitation.
The hospital shall maintain a sanitary environment to prevent the spread of communicable diseases and infections.
The hospital shall have systems to maintain the environment in a clean and sanitary condition.

Systems shall be provided to ensure that housekeeping, linen handling, waste disposal including medical waste, food handling, ventilation systems, water systems, and pest control meet acceptable federal and State standards and guidelines.
Aseptic Technique. The hospital shall use aseptic techniques to prevent infections, including surgical site infections and device-associated infections.
Immunocompromised Patients. The hospital shall use professionally accepted procedures to protect immunocompromised patients from infection.
Standard Precautions. The hospital staff shall use standard precautions and other categories of isolation or precautions consistent with current Center for Disease Control (CDC) recommendations.
Equipment and Supplies.
The hospital shall have personal protective equipment, such as gloves, gowns, respirators, and masks or other facial protection for staff readily available.
Supplies and equipment needed to prevent the spread of communicable diseases and infections shall be available in all patient care areas.

Employee Health Program. The infection prevention and control program shall work in conjunction with the employee health program and include monitoring and identification of employee health concerns such as immunity to measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella (chicken pox).

Immunizations for influenza shall be offered to staff and licensed independent practitioners. Reasons for refusal of the influenza vaccine by an employee shall be documented by the infection control or employee health program.
Performance Improvement.

The infection prevention and control program shall include performance improvement and quality assurance measures to address the problems identified through the surveillance, control, and investigation of infections.
The hospital shall develop and implement interventions to address identified problems and monitor the effectiveness of interventions to control and prevent infections.
The infection prevention and control program shall be incorporated into the hospital's performance improvement program.

Patient Safety. The infection prevention and control program shall share data regarding healthcare-associated infections with the hospital's designated patient safety officer. Health care associated infections that meet the definition of a Level 1 adverse event shall be reported to the Department, and a root cause analysis submitted as required by COMAR 10.07.06.
Reports to the Governing Body.
Infection control data including reports on the numbers and types of healthcare-associated infections shall be reported to the hospital's medical staff and governing body on an ongoing basis.
The hospital leadership shall support infection prevention and control activities, including the provision of adequate resources for the program.
Department Oversight.

The hospital shall comply with all data reporting requirements of the Maryland Health Care Commission related to the prevention and acquisition of infections in accordance with Health-General Article, §19-134(e), Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Department shall have access to all data maintained through the hospital's infection prevention and control program to determine the hospital's compliance with State and federal regulations.
A hospital shall provide a patient or legal guardian of a patient with an opportunity to designate one lay caregiver before the discharge of the patient to their residence.
The hospital’s discharge planning shall include the designation of the lay caregiver as soon as practicable in the discharge planning process.
If a patient or legal guardian of a patient declines to designate a lay caregiver, the hospital shall:
Document the decision in the patient’s medical record; and
Be deemed to be in compliance with this regulation.
If a patient or legal guardian of a patient designates a lay caregiver the hospital shall record in the patient’s medical record:
The designation of the lay caregiver;
The relationship of the lay caregiver to the patient; and
The name, telephone number, and address of the lay caregiver.
Release of Medical Information.

If the patient designates a lay caregiver, the hospital shall request the patient or legal guardian to consent in writing to release medical information to the lay caregiver. The release of records shall be in accordance with:
The hospital’s procedures for releasing personal health information; and
All applicable federal and State laws.
If a patient or legal guardian of a patient declines to consent to the release of medical information to the lay caregiver, the hospital is not required to:
Provide to the lay caregiver the notice required under Health-General Article, §19-382, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Consult with the lay caregiver or provide to the lay caregiver information contained in the discharge plan issued under Health-General Article, §19-383, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A patient or a legal guardian of the patient may change the designation of a lay caregiver in the event the lay caregiver becomes incapacitated.
Regardless of the desire of the patient or legal guardian of the patient, the designated lay caregiver is not obligated to perform any aftercare for the patient.
A patient or legal guardian is not required to designate a lay caregiver.
Hospital Obligations.

If a patient or legal guardian of a patient designates a lay caregiver, the hospital shall notify the lay caregiver as soon as practicable of the discharge of the patient or the patient’s transfer to another hospital, licensed health care facility or other residential facility.
As soon as practicable before the discharge of a patient, the hospital shall attempt to:
Consult with the patient’s lay caregiver to prepare the lay caregiver for the patient’s aftercare; and
Issue a discharge plan that describes the aftercare needs of the patient.
The hospital shall make reasonable attempts to consult with the lay caregiver.
The inability of the hospital to consult with a lay caregiver may not interfere with, delay, or otherwise affect the medical care provided to the patient or the patient’s planned discharge.
The hospital shall document successful or unsuccessful attempts to contact the lay caregiver.
Discharge Planning Requirements. Regardless of the request for the designation of a lay caregiver, the hospital shall comply with all discharge planning requirements in:
Regulation .27 of this chapter;
The standards imposed under the hospital’s accreditation by a State-approved accreditation organization; and
The designation of a lay caregiver may not:
Interfere with the rights of an agent to make health care decisions under Health-General Article, Title 5, Subtitle 6, Annotated Code of Maryland; or

Create a private right of action against a hospital, a hospital employee, or a duly authorized agent of a hospital or otherwise supersede or replace existing rights or remedies under any other State or federal law.
A hospital shall develop a listing of the rights of patients that is consistent with the requirements of:
The Joint Commission;
Health-General Article, §19-342, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
The hospital’s patient rights shall at minimum address:
Patient privacy and confidentiality;
Informed decision making and informed consent;
Visitation;
Advance directives;
Access to patient medical records;
Complaint and grievance process;
Freedom from:
Physical or mental abuse;
Neglect;
Harassment; or
Mistreatment;
A patient’s right to expect and receive appropriate assessment, management, and treatment of pain as an integral component of the patient’s care; and
Communication in a manner the patient can understand.
All patients receiving services at the hospital, have the right to receive written copies of the hospital’s patient rights upon request.
The hospital’s patient rights shall be easily accessible to patients and visitors.
Hospital staff who are responsible for patient care shall:
Receive training regarding the hospital’s patient rights; and
Be able to assist patients and their families to:
Access the services of the hospital’s patient advocacy staff;
File a complaint or grievance; or
Obtain a written copy of the hospital’s patient rights documents.
